chapter.title: Cash Register Maintenance
chapter.para: As the manager of a retail store you are responsible for managing the Cash Register terminals. This responsibility includes the following duties:

listitem.para: Opening and closing registers each business day
Adjusting funds in and out of registers during operation
Monitoring transaction history throughout the day
Reconciling registers at the end of business day

chapter.para: This chapter covers all these topics in detail and highlights tools and functionality that will make your job easier.

section.title: Opening the Cash Register Terminal
section.para: The first task at hand each day after turning on the lights and before unlocking the doors of your store is to open your Cash Register terminals for business. For the scenarios described in this chapter, we will assume we have all privileges on all Cash Registers—and that we are running a multi-Site retail operation. The following path will get you to the list of Cash Register terminals: Sales > Retail > Cash Registers.
As the following screenshot illustrates, our sample retail operation consists of five registers (TERMINALS 1A-2B) spread across two different Sites (ST1 and ST2):

For this exercise, we will assume we are managing Store Front 1 (ST1). We expect it will be a slow shopping day. And at this point all we want to do is open the TERMINAL 1A Cash Register. As you can see, all the Cash Registers are currently closed—and all have a $0 balance.
To open TERMINAL 1A, follow these steps:

listitem.para: Highlight TERMINAL 1A
Select the USE button

tip.para: You can also double-click a register to open it.

section.para: Once you open the register, you are presented with the following screen:
The main register screen provides information about pending Sales for the register—as well as links to other features will we will explore in other sections.
Meanwhile, let's continue our focus on basic Cash Register maintenance. To reach the maintenance area, select the "Maintain" tab. The following screen will appear:

Our task this morning is to open TERMINAL 1A with a balance of $250—and that's exactly what we are going to do. As you can see in the screenshot, the maintenance screen allows for bank transfers and also adjustments. For now, we will focus on bank transfers, because we want to get the register open and ready for business. Later, we will discuss how to handle miscellaneous adjustments.
To open the register, follow these steps:

listitem.para: From the "Action" field, select the "Open" option
Under the "Bank Transfer" section, choose the Bank Account you want to transfer money from
Enter the amount of money you want to transfer into the terminal (i.e., $250 in our example)
Specify "In" next to the "Amount" field to indicate money is going into the terminal
Note the New Balance amount—and make sure it is correct

Make sure the "Print Receipt" option is selected. (The default print settings can be changed using the OPTIONS button. These settings are particular to this screen—and to the terminal you are working on.)
Finally, select the POST button
Your register is now ready to begin processing Sales!

tip.para: If cash for opening balances is maintained on the store premises in a safe, you can create an asset account and a Bank Account for your safe. This will help you closely track all funds transferred between register, safe, and bank.

section.para: Returning to the Cash Register list, we now see that TERMINAL 1A is ready for business:
Not only is TERMINAL 1A showing as active, but it also has a time stamp indicating when the register was opened. The current opening balance for the register is also indicated.

section.title: Adjusting the Cash Register Terminal
section.para: It's not uncommon for a Cash Register to be thrown out of balance during the course of the business day. Sometimes the balance due is counted out wrong, and sometimes you'll have a customer who wants the store to keep the change. In these instances—when overages or losses are encountered—it's important to have a mechanism enabling managers to make minor adjustments. Once again, user permissions define who in the store has the ability to adjust the register balance.
If a Cash Register adjustment is required, use the "Adjustment" section of the maintenance window, as shown in the following screen:
The adjustment process is similar to opening a register. For this example, let's say the Cash Register is over by $0.85—due to a transaction error. To adjust for an overage, follow these steps:

listitem.para: From the "Action" field, select the "Adjust" option
Enter $0.85 as the amount to be transferred in or out of the register
Specify "Out" next to the "Amount" field to indicate money is going out of the terminal
Finally, select the POST button
Notice the current balance updates after adjustment is posted

note.para: Be careful not to confuse the adjustment transaction with the bank transfer transaction. Adjustments should be used for money that is not accounted for by any other type of transaction. For example, if your cash drawer becomes full on a particularly busy shopping day and you need to transfer money out of the drawer and into a safe, use the bank transfer transaction.

section.title: Closing the Cash Register
section.para: Once the business day is over, you are ready to close and reconcile the Cash Register. Closing the Cash Register also updates the General Ledger (G/L) with all the sales and cash transaction information generated during the course of the day. This final accounting for sales and cash information only hits the G/L when the Cash Register is closed. By contrast, inventory movement is tracked in the G/L on a sale-by-sale basis.

For this example, we will be transferring all the cash out of the TERMINAL 1A Cash Register—and depositing it into our Bank Account. We will also plan to deposit any Checks we have received during the day. To do this, follow these steps:

listitem.para: From the "Action" field, select the "Close" option
Under the "Bank Transfer" section, choose the Bank Account you want to transfer money to
Enter the amount of cash you want to transfer to the Bank Account

note.para: Keep in mind that the current balance in the register includes only cash. Checks are not included in the current balance amount.

listitem.para: By default, the "Deposit Checks" option should be automatically selected

note.para: The "Deposit Checks" option ensures that the total amount of Check Sales for the register will be recorded in the General Ledger.

listitem.para: Verify the "Print Receipt" option is selected in the lower left-hand corner of the screen
Select the POST button
View the Cash Register receipt

section.para: If the sum of the physical cash and Checks from the register equal the totals on the Register Posting Receipt, you're ready to make your bank deposit.

In the event that your Cash Register terminal does not balance you can review the Detailed Register History screen to research transaction errors. Use the following path to reach the detailed history screen: Sales > Reports > Detailed Register History.

You will notice from the screen shot above this screen provides detailed information such as transaction type, user, tender, and items purchased. This screen also gives you the ability to search by a specific terminal on a specific date. While in our example the Cash Register actually balanced we may need to research other information. For example, perhaps customer 102 is a notorious check bouncer and we would like to find out how many purchases they made today. We can see from the report that this customer made two purchases on TERMINAL 1A and wrote two checks 3455 and 1990. The store manager could then flag these checks to verify funds.

section.title: Cash Register Maintenance History
section.para: You can review register history at any time to determine when a terminal was opened, closed, and adjusted. Use the following path to reach the register history screen: Sales > Reports > Register History.

In this screen shot we can see on the first line that TERMINAL 1A was opened on 3/12/09 and $250 was transferred in the Cash Register. This screen could be very useful in a multi-site operation where a manager may want to find out how many registers are open at each store or if a manager reports to work mid-day and needs to know which terminals are open at the store.
